fullProgramDescription: The Linguistics major with a Specialization in Cognition and Language is designed for students interested in the study of language as it relates to the mind. The program covers the core areas of linguistics, including phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics, as well as the cognitive aspects of language processing and acquisition.
shortProgramDescription: The Linguistics major with a Specialization in Cognition and Language prepares students for careers or further study in areas related to the cognitive aspects of language.
classHighlights: Core linguistics courses, including Introduction to Linguistics (LING100), Phonetics and Phonology (LING101A), Morphology (LING102), Syntax (LING103), and Semantics (LING104), provide a foundation in the study of language structure.

Courses in cognition and language, such as Language Acquisition (LING120), Psycholinguistics (LING121), and Neurolinguistics (LING122), focus on the mental processes involved in language processing and acquisition.
Electives in areas such as phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics allow students to explore specific topics in linguistics and cognition.
Additional courses in computer science, psychology, or philosophy may be recommended or required to support the student's understanding of cognitive aspects of language.
Upper-division courses, such as Linguistic Theory (LING201A-B) and Research Methods in Linguistics (LING210), provide advanced training in linguistic theory and research methods.
learningOutcomes: Understand the core areas of linguistics, including phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics.
Analyze language data using linguistic theories and methods.
Apply knowledge of linguistic structures to understand language processing and acquisition.
Evaluate the cognitive aspects of language and their relation to the mind.
Demonstrate an understanding of the interdisciplinary nature of linguistics and cognition.
creditRequirements: Total of180 quarter units required for graduation; major requires specific courses and electives
additionalInformation: Students must satisfy the upper-division writing requirement; some courses may have prerequisites or require departmental approval.
